pr_title: Clarify instructions in the custom checker wpi script

timeline.message: clarify instructions in the custom checker script

timeline.bodyText: Rather than modifying the last command, I think this script would be easier to use if there is logic that checks whether the variable is set and provides the --stubs option only if the variable is set.  Similarly for --libs.
timeline.author: mernst
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -24,7 +24,9 @@ checkername=no-literal
 repolist=securerandom.list
 workingdir=$(pwd)
 
-# the stub files for the checker being used
+# The stub files for the checker being used.
+# If you are not using stub files, you MUST comment this line out and modify the last command in

replies.bodyText: I don't disagree that the change you're suggesting would make the script easier to use. However, this script isn't meant to be used - it is an example/template for a user to write their own script. For that reason, the script's logic should be as simple as possible - the "user" is expected to read and understand the entire script, modifying each line for their use-case as they go. No one should run this script without first understanding it and modifying it themselves.
replies.author: kelloggm

replies.bodyText: The fewer modifications are necessary, the fewer errors users are likely to make.  I think it is better to make the script just a little bit more capable, rather than leaving landmines for less-than-perfect users to stumble over.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I wouldn't think these variables should be quoted, because they represent multiple tokens.  If this works as is, then fine.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: My understanding has always been that variables that might be empty or contain whitespace should be quoted. This version also passes shellcheck as-is, though I didn't actually run the script (I don't have the environment to do so anymore).
replies.author: kelloggm

replies.bodyText:
If the variable is empty, your goal is not to pass a single empty token to the program; rather, your goal is to pass no tokens to the program.
Shellcheck assumes you want to pass a single token; a warning suppression is necessary in cases like this.
replies.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Thanks for the explanation. I looked through https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck/wiki/SC2086 and found an alternative that avoids the shellcheck warning but also has the behavior we're looking for, I think, using alternate expansion (the discussion of this approach is near the bottom of that page).
replies.author: kelloggm
